title: Thursday Morning Business Brief
text:
October 15, 2015, 6:14 AM TOKYO - 
Global shares rose today after weak economic figures in the U.S. reinforced expectations the Federal Reserve will remain cautious over raising interest rates. Germany's DAX rose 0.9 percent to 10,002.67 and Britain's FTSE 100 advanced 0.8 percent to 6,318.16. The French CAC40 also gained 0.8 percent to 4,647.14. Asian markets were higher, and U.S. markets looked set for an upbeat start, with Dow futures up 0.5 percent and S&P futures 0.6 percent higher. Reports on average mortgage rates, September's consumer prices and last week's unemployment claims are due out this morning. Earnings reports from UnitedHealth, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs and Philip Morris are also set for release before Wall Street opens. BERLIN (AP) - Germany's motor transport agency is ordering a mandatory recall of 2.4 million Volkswagen cars sold with software that enabled them to evade diesel emissions testing. The dpa news agency reports that the Federal Motor Transport Authority rejected a Volkswagen proposal for a voluntary recall. Germany's transport minister says Volkswagen would have to present replacement software for certain cars that have a 2.0 liter diesel engine this month and begin fitting vehicles with them next year. The recall could last through 2016. CHICAGO (AP) - Five down, one to go. Chicago's O'Hare International Airport is set to open a new runway and air traffic control tower today, completing another piece of the $9 billion overhaul of its outdated airfield. Chicago has been untangling O'Hare's six crisscrossing runways and rearranging them in a safer, more efficient side-by-side layout that's supposed to unclog one of the country's worst aviation bottlenecks. The airport is generally last in the rankings for on-time performance. BEIJING (AP) - The rise of fortunes in technology and manufacturing has given China more billionaires than the United States, according to a survey released today. The Hurun Report follows the Asian country's wealthy and pegs the number of billionaires in China at 596. The U.S. has 537. Â© 2015 Associated Press. All rights reserved.
